content: Finally, after 18 months of heartache, this morning, my childrens father was served with papers for paternity and child support. While it should feel like a victory, it doesn't. He leaves for Iraq on Tuesday, and it's possibe that he will now have yet another YEAR to escape his responsibilities to his children for another year, bringing it to two and a half years that this man will not have supported his children. He has 20 days to answer the petition. If he doesn't respond at all, we should win by default. But in child support cases where the military is involved deadbeat dads get a free pass if they're 'active duty.'

content: Ma'am, It is hardly considered a "free pass" because he is active duty. There are rules and regulations that all courts have to follow when serving active duty members of the military that protect said active duty member from not being able to appear in court because of deployment. So yes, you will have to wait until he gets back from his deployment to go to court, a default judgement cannot be placed against him while he is deployed. That is just how it works and the fact that at 1 1/2 years you haven't just cut your losses and moved on worries me that you only see him as a paycheck at this point. Please remember what you are putting your children through at this point of forcing someone into their life that doesn't want to be there.

content: Numbers--I don't know how your state works, but in the state where my CS case is, the Child Support owed was retroactive to the date on which I applied for CS. As in: I applied for CS in November 2004 and it wasn't set in a Hearing until May 2005 (yes that states CS courts are that busy!) but when the amount was set the Judge ordered him to pay from November when I'd applied. So he paid the regular monthly amount, and another small amount towards that November-May "arrears". Hope it all works out for you....but keep in mind that what YOU want to happen, and what the law says is proper procedure, may be two different things....and it's on you to roll with that and be an adult about it. As has been said, if you couldn't afford the children, you shouldn't have had them.....but you DID, and now it's time to stop whining about what you're NOT getting and raise your children. Whether it's on your own or with Child Support. My Mom did it with 3 kids and not one dime of CS ever, while in Nursing school and working, it CAN be done contrary to many womens belief.

content: quote: Military service can't be used as an excuse to avoid family/child care or expenses - - If fact, if the guy is REALLY messing up, it can lead to him getting the boot! Not an excuse, but the Service members Civil Relief Act (formerly known as the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act) exist to protect deployed troops who cannot "defend themselves" in civil court due to military taskings. Personal experience: My "Ex" had me served with divorce papers 3 days before I was to leave on a one year remote assignment, her motivation was that I would not be able to react in time to defend myself and that she would receive a judgment in my absence. I got a lawyer and they suspended the divorce proceedings until I returned to the states. If my Ex used this tactic...others such as this writer may well be attempting the same thing. I'll not pass judgment one way of the other without all the facts, but the timing is suspicious. That said...clearly, this father needs to participate in the welfare of his children to some extent. Equally clear is that this Mother didn't need to WAIT until just before a deployment to take action. If the Father does engage a lawyer he may well be granted a stay until he can return...if he does not...he will most likely have a judgment against him without ever setting foot in a court room.

content: Mfamily2004- I started this in Nov of 07. There were complications because of my marital status and haveing CSE instead of a real attorney. There were solutions to the problem if I'd had a real attorney, but this was not the case, so the point is moot. The issue here is not whether or not I will be awarded support and back support. The issue is that he's only in the "Reserves." He has known he had kids. He joined without disclosing it, and when we NEEDED him to provide for us a year ago, he COULD HAVE while he was at AIT and Boot Camp. But to protect his 'bonus' from being gonoshiered for the BACK child support, he wouldn't just sign their birth certificates and SUPPORT THEM. And he is only in the reserves. Once his tour in Iraq is over, full time pay and dependent pay stop, he will only get his 'weekend' pay and he'll work off the books. So I'll have a judgment for two and a half years of back child support. It's a worthless piece of paper. Proper procedure went out the window the day he lied about having kids. And FYI, I could afford my kids when I had them. He pushed to have a family (and he was NOT a soldier at the time and gave me NO indication that he would EVER become one), AND HE HAD THEM TOO. Not a case of I trapped him. He wanted them, but then he wanted out, still claiming he wants to be in their lives, but using every dirty little deadbeat dad trick to get away with supporting them. I would have never even had kids if he hadn't wanted them. So please, don't tell me that I 'need to take care of them.' I'm HERE... I AM taking care of them. I'm not the one who walked. But taking care of them isn't something I just 'HAVE TO DO' and he DOESN'T. How would you expect anyone to make him take care of his kids if I passively sit by 'taking care of his responsibilities' and don't pursue and push to get done what should have been done a year ago? And good for your mom for doing it on her own. That only bred a generation of women who let men off the hook, and a generation of deadbeat dads. Women who aren't fighting to HOLD MEN ACCOUNTABLE for their kids, are why it's so easy for our country to have a 50% divorce rate. Men can walk any time they want to because of people who think it's ok to tell the mother 'you had them.' Do you realize the difference of the $500.00 a month I would get in 'child support' and the $40,000 a year income lost when Daddy walked out? It's a huge difference in the lives of the kids, and that's just the financials. The emotional cost is even greater. The only way men are ever going to learn what it means to be MEN, FATHERS, and HUSBANDS... is when people stop saying "oh, well, you're not getting child support. You still have to take care of the kids. Forget it and move on." And this is the society our men are fighting to protect.

content: In fairness to the OP, allow me to post my story. And before you think this is BS, it's been vetted by a good number of people here. My ex had 3 kids when we married. I adopted them, I raised them, and I babysat them when she wet to the police academy. She had an affair with another cop and then she dumped me. She went to the courts in her perty new uniform and had a restraining order taken out on me. That included the kids. Just a few days ago I got an email from my middle daughter - she has to sneak around, as her mom won't let us communicate even that way. She wants me to call the ex's best friend. So I do. Turns out that my ex has been lying to everyone all along. Badge bunny. She has no friends, no family, no nothing but her job. Her oldest is 18, pregnant -- no idea who dad is -- and just ran away from jail. The middle one that I am close to is squared away, but the ex refuses her permission to speak to me. The boy, who is younger, has taken to peeking under the best friend's sheets after her husband leaves. We split 4 years ago. She still blames all this on me. This was after she had me ARRESTED for a crime I never committed. So don't sit here and lecture ME about men being protected. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: 21482921, IF you have a Court order for child support signed by a judge, send it to DFAS. Action will be taken even if the member is in a drilling status as a reserve member, on active duty or currently deployed. Taken from the DFAS website: Federal law authorizes the pay of active, reserve, and retired members of the military and the pay of civilian employees of the Federal government to be garnished (or attached) for the payment of child and/or spousal support. The law is found at 42 U.S.C. 659, and the implementing regulation is found at 5 C.F.R. Part 581. To implement a garnishment or wage attachment against any member of the military or any civilian employee of the Department of Defense (DoD), an income withholding order or similar process must be served upon DFAS at the following address: Defense Finance and Accounting Service Cleveland DFAS-DGG/CL PO Box 998002 Cleveland Ohio 44199-8002 1-888-332-7411 (toll free Customer Service) For child support, you might want to contact either an attorney, or your local child support enforcement agency in order to obtain an Income Deduction Order or Income Withholding Order. For alimony, you might want to contact an attorney to obtain a garnishment. To collect the support/alimony you were ordered to receive, we need an order from a court or child support enforcement agency (CSEA) that directs the government to pay monies for support or alimony. You do not need to send the underlying order, (e.g., a divorce/separation decree). The order submitted cannot be the divorce decree or other order that directs the individual (obligor) to make the payment. Rather, the order must direct the government, as the employer, to withhold moneys and remit payments to satisfy the support obligation. The withholding order need not name the specific government office in which the obligor is employed. The order must provide the appropriate information about the person to receive payment. For your withholding order to be processed, it must include the obligor's full legal name and social security number. Also, please include your return address on any correspondence, not only on the mailing envelope. Questions concerning the child support and alimony processes can be directed to 1-888-DFAS-411 or 1-888- 332-7411. Garnishment Operations Facsimile (FAX) Information: Fax Phone Number: Commercial (216) 522-6960 or DSN 580-6960 or toll free:1-877-622-5930.

content: Ma'am, It is hardly considered a "free pass" because he is active duty. There are rules and regulations that all courts have to follow when serving active duty members of the military that protect said active duty member from not being able to appear in court because of deployment. So yes, you will have to wait until he gets back from his deployment to go to court, a default judgement cannot be placed against him while he is deployed. That is just how it works and the fact that at 1 1/2 years you haven't just cut your losses and moved on worries me that you only see him as a paycheck at this point. Please remember what you are putting your children through at this point of forcing someone into their life that doesn't want to be there.

content: Numbers--I don't know how your state works, but in the state where my CS case is, the Child Support owed was retroactive to the date on which I applied for CS. As in: I applied for CS in November 2004 and it wasn't set in a Hearing until May 2005 (yes that states CS courts are that busy!) but when the amount was set the Judge ordered him to pay from November when I'd applied. So he paid the regular monthly amount, and another small amount towards that November-May "arrears". Hope it all works out for you....but keep in mind that what YOU want to happen, and what the law says is proper procedure, may be two different things....and it's on you to roll with that and be an adult about it. As has been said, if you couldn't afford the children, you shouldn't have had them.....but you DID, and now it's time to stop whining about what you're NOT getting and raise your children. Whether it's on your own or with Child Support. My Mom did it with 3 kids and not one dime of CS ever, while in Nursing school and working, it CAN be done contrary to many womens belief.

content: quote: Military service can't be used as an excuse to avoid family/child care or expenses - - If fact, if the guy is REALLY messing up, it can lead to him getting the boot! Not an excuse, but the Service members Civil Relief Act (formerly known as the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act) exist to protect deployed troops who cannot "defend themselves" in civil court due to military taskings. Personal experience: My "Ex" had me served with divorce papers 3 days before I was to leave on a one year remote assignment, her motivation was that I would not be able to react in time to defend myself and that she would receive a judgment in my absence. I got a lawyer and they suspended the divorce proceedings until I returned to the states. If my Ex used this tactic...others such as this writer may well be attempting the same thing. I'll not pass judgment one way of the other without all the facts, but the timing is suspicious. That said...clearly, this father needs to participate in the welfare of his children to some extent. Equally clear is that this Mother didn't need to WAIT until just before a deployment to take action. If the Father does engage a lawyer he may well be granted a stay until he can return...if he does not...he will most likely have a judgment against him without ever setting foot in a court room.

content: Mfamily2004- I started this in Nov of 07. There were complications because of my marital status and haveing CSE instead of a real attorney. There were solutions to the problem if I'd had a real attorney, but this was not the case, so the point is moot. The issue here is not whether or not I will be awarded support and back support. The issue is that he's only in the "Reserves." He has known he had kids. He joined without disclosing it, and when we NEEDED him to provide for us a year ago, he COULD HAVE while he was at AIT and Boot Camp. But to protect his 'bonus' from being gonoshiered for the BACK child support, he wouldn't just sign their birth certificates and SUPPORT THEM. And he is only in the reserves. Once his tour in Iraq is over, full time pay and dependent pay stop, he will only get his 'weekend' pay and he'll work off the books. So I'll have a judgment for two and a half years of back child support. It's a worthless piece of paper. Proper procedure went out the window the day he lied about having kids. And FYI, I could afford my kids when I had them. He pushed to have a family (and he was NOT a soldier at the time and gave me NO indication that he would EVER become one), AND HE HAD THEM TOO. Not a case of I trapped him. He wanted them, but then he wanted out, still claiming he wants to be in their lives, but using every dirty little deadbeat dad trick to get away with supporting them. I would have never even had kids if he hadn't wanted them. So please, don't tell me that I 'need to take care of them.' I'm HERE... I AM taking care of them. I'm not the one who walked. But taking care of them isn't something I just 'HAVE TO DO' and he DOESN'T. How would you expect anyone to make him take care of his kids if I passively sit by 'taking care of his responsibilities' and don't pursue and push to get done what should have been done a year ago? And good for your mom for doing it on her own. That only bred a generation of women who let men off the hook, and a generation of deadbeat dads. Women who aren't fighting to HOLD MEN ACCOUNTABLE for their kids, are why it's so easy for our country to have a 50% divorce rate. Men can walk any time they want to because of people who think it's ok to tell the mother 'you had them.' Do you realize the difference of the $500.00 a month I would get in 'child support' and the $40,000 a year income lost when Daddy walked out? It's a huge difference in the lives of the kids, and that's just the financials. The emotional cost is even greater. The only way men are ever going to learn what it means to be MEN, FATHERS, and HUSBANDS... is when people stop saying "oh, well, you're not getting child support. You still have to take care of the kids. Forget it and move on." And this is the society our men are fighting to protect.

content: 21482921, IF you have a Court order for child support signed by a judge, send it to DFAS. Action will be taken even if the member is in a drilling status as a reserve member, on active duty or currently deployed. Taken from the DFAS website: Federal law authorizes the pay of active, reserve, and retired members of the military and the pay of civilian employees of the Federal government to be garnished (or attached) for the payment of child and/or spousal support. The law is found at 42 U.S.C. 659, and the implementing regulation is found at 5 C.F.R. Part 581. To implement a garnishment or wage attachment against any member of the military or any civilian employee of the Department of Defense (DoD), an income withholding order or similar process must be served upon DFAS at the following address: Defense Finance and Accounting Service Cleveland DFAS-DGG/CL PO Box 998002 Cleveland Ohio 44199-8002 1-888-332-7411 (toll free Customer Service) For child support, you might want to contact either an attorney, or your local child support enforcement agency in order to obtain an Income Deduction Order or Income Withholding Order. For alimony, you might want to contact an attorney to obtain a garnishment. To collect the support/alimony you were ordered to receive, we need an order from a court or child support enforcement agency (CSEA) that directs the government to pay monies for support or alimony. You do not need to send the underlying order, (e.g., a divorce/separation decree). The order submitted cannot be the divorce decree or other order that directs the individual (obligor) to make the payment. Rather, the order must direct the government, as the employer, to withhold moneys and remit payments to satisfy the support obligation. The withholding order need not name the specific government office in which the obligor is employed. The order must provide the appropriate information about the person to receive payment. For your withholding order to be processed, it must include the obligor's full legal name and social security number. Also, please include your return address on any correspondence, not only on the mailing envelope. Questions concerning the child support and alimony processes can be directed to 1-888-DFAS-411 or 1-888- 332-7411. Garnishment Operations Facsimile (FAX) Information: Fax Phone Number: Commercial (216) 522-6960 or DSN 580-6960 or toll free:1-877-622-5930.

content: Ma'am, It is hardly considered a "free pass" because he is active duty. There are rules and regulations that all courts have to follow when serving active duty members of the military that protect said active duty member from not being able to appear in court because of deployment. So yes, you will have to wait until he gets back from his deployment to go to court, a default judgement cannot be placed against him while he is deployed. That is just how it works and the fact that at 1 1/2 years you haven't just cut your losses and moved on worries me that you only see him as a paycheck at this point. Please remember what you are putting your children through at this point of forcing someone into their life that doesn't want to be there.

content: Numbers--I don't know how your state works, but in the state where my CS case is, the Child Support owed was retroactive to the date on which I applied for CS. As in: I applied for CS in November 2004 and it wasn't set in a Hearing until May 2005 (yes that states CS courts are that busy!) but when the amount was set the Judge ordered him to pay from November when I'd applied. So he paid the regular monthly amount, and another small amount towards that November-May "arrears". Hope it all works out for you....but keep in mind that what YOU want to happen, and what the law says is proper procedure, may be two different things....and it's on you to roll with that and be an adult about it. As has been said, if you couldn't afford the children, you shouldn't have had them.....but you DID, and now it's time to stop whining about what you're NOT getting and raise your children. Whether it's on your own or with Child Support. My Mom did it with 3 kids and not one dime of CS ever, while in Nursing school and working, it CAN be done contrary to many womens belief.

content: quote: Military service can't be used as an excuse to avoid family/child care or expenses - - If fact, if the guy is REALLY messing up, it can lead to him getting the boot! Not an excuse, but the Service members Civil Relief Act (formerly known as the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act) exist to protect deployed troops who cannot "defend themselves" in civil court due to military taskings. Personal experience: My "Ex" had me served with divorce papers 3 days before I was to leave on a one year remote assignment, her motivation was that I would not be able to react in time to defend myself and that she would receive a judgment in my absence. I got a lawyer and they suspended the divorce proceedings until I returned to the states. If my Ex used this tactic...others such as this writer may well be attempting the same thing. I'll not pass judgment one way of the other without all the facts, but the timing is suspicious. That said...clearly, this father needs to participate in the welfare of his children to some extent. Equally clear is that this Mother didn't need to WAIT until just before a deployment to take action. If the Father does engage a lawyer he may well be granted a stay until he can return...if he does not...he will most likely have a judgment against him without ever setting foot in a court room.

I got a lawyer and they suspended the divorce proceedings until I returned to the states. If my Ex used this tactic...others such as this writer may well be attempting the same thing. I'll not pass judgment one way of the other without all the facts, but the timing is suspicious. That said...clearly, this father needs to participate in the welfare of his children to some extent. Equally clear is that this Mother didn't need to WAIT until just before a deployment to take action. If the Father does engage a lawyer he may well be granted a stay until he can return...if he does not...he will most likely have a judgment against him without ever setting foot in a court room.
title: He's been served.

content: Mfamily2004- I started this in Nov of 07. There were complications because of my marital status and haveing CSE instead of a real attorney. There were solutions to the problem if I'd had a real attorney, but this was not the case, so the point is moot. The issue here is not whether or not I will be awarded support and back support. The issue is that he's only in the "Reserves." He has known he had kids. He joined without disclosing it, and when we NEEDED him to provide for us a year ago, he COULD HAVE while he was at AIT and Boot Camp. But to protect his 'bonus' from being gonoshiered for the BACK child support, he wouldn't just sign their birth certificates and SUPPORT THEM. And he is only in the reserves. Once his tour in Iraq is over, full time pay and dependent pay stop, he will only get his 'weekend' pay and he'll work off the books. So I'll have a judgment for two and a half years of back child support. It's a worthless piece of paper. Proper procedure went out the window the day he lied about having kids. And FYI, I could afford my kids when I had them. He pushed to have a family (and he was NOT a soldier at the time and gave me NO indication that he would EVER become one), AND HE HAD THEM TOO. Not a case of I trapped him. He wanted them, but then he wanted out, still claiming he wants to be in their lives, but using every dirty little deadbeat dad trick to get away with supporting them. I would have never even had kids if he hadn't wanted them. So please, don't tell me that I 'need to take care of them.' I'm HERE... I AM taking care of them. I'm not the one who walked. But taking care of them isn't something I just 'HAVE TO DO' and he DOESN'T. How would you expect anyone to make him take care of his kids if I passively sit by 'taking care of his responsibilities' and don't pursue and push to get done what should have been done a year ago? And good for your mom for doing it on her own. That only bred a generation of women who let men off the hook, and a generation of deadbeat dads. Women who aren't fighting to HOLD MEN ACCOUNTABLE for their kids, are why it's so easy for our country to have a 50% divorce rate. Men can walk any time they want to because of people who think it's ok to tell the mother 'you had them.' Do you realize the difference of the $500.00 a month I would get in 'child support' and the $40,000 a year income lost when Daddy walked out? It's a huge difference in the lives of the kids, and that's just the financials. The emotional cost is even greater. The only way men are ever going to learn what it means to be MEN, FATHERS, and HUSBANDS... is when people stop saying "oh, well, you're not getting child support. You still have to take care of the kids. Forget it and move on." And this is the society our men are fighting to protect.

content: In fairness to the OP, allow me to post my story. And before you think this is BS, it's been vetted by a good number of people here. My ex had 3 kids when we married. I adopted them, I raised them, and I babysat them when she wet to the police academy. She had an affair with another cop and then she dumped me. She went to the courts in her perty new uniform and had a restraining order taken out on me. That included the kids. Just a few days ago I got an email from my middle daughter - she has to sneak around, as her mom won't let us communicate even that way. She wants me to call the ex's best friend. So I do. Turns out that my ex has been lying to everyone all along. Badge bunny. She has no friends, no family, no nothing but her job. Her oldest is 18, pregnant -- no idea who dad is -- and just ran away from jail. The middle one that I am close to is squared away, but the ex refuses her permission to speak to me. The boy, who is younger, has taken to peeking under the best friend's sheets after her husband leaves. We split 4 years ago. She still blames all this on me. This was after she had me ARRESTED for a crime I never committed. So don't sit here and lecture ME about men being protected. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: 21482921, IF you have a Court order for child support signed by a judge, send it to DFAS. Action will be taken even if the member is in a drilling status as a reserve member, on active duty or currently deployed. Taken from the DFAS website: Federal law authorizes the pay of active, reserve, and retired members of the military and the pay of civilian employees of the Federal government to be garnished (or attached) for the payment of child and/or spousal support. The law is found at 42 U.S.C. 659, and the implementing regulation is found at 5 C.F.R. Part 581. To implement a garnishment or wage attachment against any member of the military or any civilian employee of the Department of Defense (DoD), an income withholding order or similar process must be served upon DFAS at the following address: Defense Finance and Accounting Service Cleveland DFAS-DGG/CL PO Box 998002 Cleveland Ohio 44199-8002 1-888-332-7411 (toll free Customer Service) For child support, you might want to contact either an attorney, or your local child support enforcement agency in order to obtain an Income Deduction Order or Income Withholding Order. For alimony, you might want to contact an attorney to obtain a garnishment. To collect the support/alimony you were ordered to receive, we need an order from a court or child support enforcement agency (CSEA) that directs the government to pay monies for support or alimony. You do not need to send the underlying order, (e.g., a divorce/separation decree). The order submitted cannot be the divorce decree or other order that directs the individual (obligor) to make the payment. Rather, the order must direct the government, as the employer, to withhold moneys and remit payments to satisfy the support obligation. The withholding order need not name the specific government office in which the obligor is employed. The order must provide the appropriate information about the person to receive payment. For your withholding order to be processed, it must include the obligor's full legal name and social security number. Also, please include your return address on any correspondence, not only on the mailing envelope. Questions concerning the child support and alimony processes can be directed to 1-888-DFAS-411 or 1-888- 332-7411. Garnishment Operations Facsimile (FAX) Information: Fax Phone Number: Commercial (216) 522-6960 or DSN 580-6960 or toll free:1-877-622-5930.
